Amendment passed on 23 March 1933 to the Weimar Constitution that gave the German Cabinet — in effect, Chancellor Adolf Hitler — the power to enact laws without the involvement of the Reichstag. The Enabling Act gave Hitler plenary powers and followed on the heels of the Reichstag Fire Decree, which had abolished most civil liberties and transferred state powers to the Reich government. The combined effect of the two laws was to transform Hitler's government into a legal dictatorship.

Boycott of German products by foreign critics of the Nazi Party in response to an organized campaign of violence and boycotting undertaken by Hitler's Nazi Party against the Jews of Germany following his appointment as Chancellor of Germany on January 30, 1933. Those in the United Kingdom, United States and other places worldwide who opposed Hitler's antisemitic policies developed the boycott and its accompanying protests to encourage Nazi Germany to end the regime's often-expressed anti-Jewish attitude.

A purge that took place in Nazi Germany from June 30 to July 2, 1934, when Adolf Hitler, urged on by Hermann Göring and Heinrich Himmler, carried out a series of political extrajudicial executions intended to consolidate his hold on power in Germany, as well as to alleviate the concerns of the German military about the role of Ernst Röhm and the Sturmabteilung (SA), the Nazis' own mass paramilitary organization. Nazi propaganda presented the murders as a preventive measure against an alleged imminent coup by the SA under Röhm – the so-called Röhm putsch

The process of Nazification by which Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party successively established a system of totalitarian control and coordination over all aspects of German society, "from the economy and trade associations to the media, culture and education”. The apex of the Nazification of Germany was in the resolutions approved during the Nuremberg Rally of 1935, when the symbols of the Nazi Party and the State were fused (see Flag of Germany) and German Jews were deprived of their citizenship (see Nuremberg Laws)

They were enacted by the Reichstag on 15 September 1935, at a special meeting convened during the annual Nuremberg Rally of the Nazi Party (NSDAP). The two laws were the Law for the Protection of German Blood and German Honour, which forbade marriages and extramarital intercourse between Jews and Germans and the employment of German females under 45 in Jewish households; and the Reich Citizenship Law, which declared that only those of German or related blood were eligible to be Reich citizens; the remainder were classed as state subjects, without citizenship rights.[1] A supplementary decree outlining the definition of who was Jewish was passed on 14 November, and the Reich Citizenship Law officially came into force on that date.[2] The laws were expanded on 26 November 1935 to include Romani people. This supplementary decree defined Romanis as "enemies of the race-based state", the same category as Jews

The Reichstag fire was an arson attack on the Reichstag building, home of the German parliament in Berlin, on Monday 27 February 1933, precisely four weeks after Adolf Hitler was sworn in as Chancellor of Germany. Hitler's government stated that Marinus van der Lubbe, a Dutch council communist, was found near the building, and they attributed the fire to communist agitators in general—though a German court decided later that year that van der Lubbe had acted alone, as he claimed. After the fire, the Reichstag Fire Decree was passed. The Nazi Party used the fire as a pretext that communists were plotting against the German government, and the event is considered pivotal in the establishment of Nazi Germany. The term "Reichstag fire" has come to refer to false flag actions facilitated by an authority to promote their own interests through popular approval of retribution or retraction of civil rights.

Kristallnacht was a pogrom against Jews throughout Nazi Germany on 9–10 November 1938, carried out by SA paramilitary forces and civilians. The German authorities looked on without intervening. The name Kristallnacht comes from the shards of broken glass that littered the streets after the windows of Jewish-owned stores, buildings, and synagogues were smashed. he pretext for the attacks was the assassination of the Nazi German diplomat Ernst vom Rath by Herschel Grynszpan, a seventeen-year-old German-born Polish Jew living in Paris. Kristallnacht was followed by additional economic and political persecution of Jews, and it is viewed by historians as part of Nazi Germany's broader racial policy, and the beginning of the Final Solution and The Holocaust. 100 Jews killed, 26,000 Jewish men arrested, destroyed many synagogues. The Jewish community was forced to pay damages for diplomats death and destruction during Kristallnacht (~$400 million).

Austria 1938, Had own offshoot of Nazi Part (illegal). Hitler was popular, movement towards unified Germany and Austria. On Feb 1938, Hilter meets with Austrian leader Shuschnigg and forced him to accept Nazis into position of political power. After that, Schurschnigg cancels it and resignes. On March 12, 1938, Wehrmacht enters Austria, aiming to create a “Greater Germany”. For Jews, it brought brutal treatment overnight.

Germany minority in Czechoslovakia, primarily in sudetenland. The Munich Conference was an agreement concluded at Munich, September 29, 1938, by Germany, Great Britain, France and Italy. It provided "cession to Germany of the Sudeten German territory" of Czechoslovakia. Most of Europe celebrated because it prevented the war threatened by Adolf Hitler by allowing Nazi Germany's annexation of the Sudetenland, a region of western Czechoslovakia inhabited by 800,000 people, mainly German speakers. Hitler announced it was his last territorial claim in Europe, and the choice seemed to be between war and appeasement. In March 1939, Germany annexes Czechoslovakia and creates a independent Slovak state. This infuriates the west by going beyond, “Self-Determinism”. This causes Britain to create guarantees with Poland, Greece, Romania and Turkey.

Blitzkrieg is a method of warfare whereby an attacking force, spearheaded by a dense concentration of armored and motorized or mechanized infantry formations with close air support, breaks through the opponent's line of defence by short, fast, powerful attacks and then dislocates the defenders, using speed and surprise to encircle them with the help of air superiority.[1][2][3] Through the employment of combined arms in manoeuvre warfare, blitzkrieg attempts to unbalance the enemy by making it difficult for it to respond to the continuously changing front, then defeat it in a decisive Vernichtungsschlacht (battle of annihilation).
After German invasion of Poland, both France and Britain declare war on Germany. France then just sits behind the Maginot Line instead of deploying troops.

Quisling is a term originating in Norway, which is used in Scandinavian languages and in English for a person who collaborates with an enemy occupying force – or more generally as a synonym for traitor. The word originates from the surname of the Norwegian war-time leader Vidkun Quisling, who headed a domestic Nazi collaborationist regime during World War II

Maginot Line is a line of concrete fortifications, obstacles, and weapon installations built by France in the 1930s to deter invasion by Germany and force them to move around the fortifications. Constructed on the French side of its borders with Italy, Switzerland, Germany, and Luxembourg, the line did not extend to the English Channel due to French strategy that envisioned a move into Belgium to counter a German assault.

Operation Barbarossa was the code name for the Axis invasion of the Soviet Union, which started on Sunday, 22 June 1941, during World War II. The operation stemmed from Nazi Germany's ideological aims to conquer the western Soviet Union so that it could be repopulated by Germans (Lebensraum), to use Slavs as a slave labour force for the Axis war effort, to murder the rest, and to acquire the oil reserves of the Caucasus and the agricultural resources of Soviet territories

Hitler stipulated that Germany required a Lebensraum ('living space') necessary for its survival and that most of the indigenous populations of Central and Eastern Europe would have to be removed permanently (either through mass deportation to Siberia, death, or enslavement) including Polish, Ukrainian, Russian, Czech and other Slavic nations considered non-Aryan. The Nazi government aimed at repopulating these lands with Germanic colonists in the name of Lebensraum during World War II and thereafter. Entire indigenous populations were decimated by starvation, allowing for their own agricultural surplus to feed Germany.
Antisemitism is hostility to, prejudice, or discrimination against Jews. A person who holds such positions is called an antisemite.

Want to move populations for Germans. More German Spaces. Part of this was the Wartheland, which was formed from parts of the Polish territory annexed. With this came, Deutsche Volksliste, A list of Germans who could settle in those German spaces.

Sketched out in 1940. Expulsion plan for large parts of Poland, Ukraine and Crimea. 30-40 million slavs either rmoved or killed. Soviet POWs were forced into a “Hunger Plan”, in winter 1941-1942, 3.3 million dead!
Initially setup to take in political prisoners in 1933. These camps pitted prisoners against each other by categorizing and separating them. Inside the camps was Disease, starvation and overcrowding.

The “Final Solution”. Initially started with killing in cities and towns, often with the help of local police that drew on longstanding anti-semitism in Europe. After “Holocaust by bullets”, the Holocaust turned to shipping people to concentration camps. Eventually, the holocaust turned to death marches as the West advanced.

The site of a major concentration camp. Transport trains delivered Jews from all over German-occupied Europe to the camp's gas chambers from early 1942 until late 1944. At least 1.1 million people died at Auschwitz of the estimated 1.3 million sent there, and some 90 percent of them were Jews. Approximately one in six Jews killed in the Holocaust died at the camp.
The requisitioning of seed grain to meet quotas and handle bad harvests. This was an attempt to eliminate Kulaks, but the famine was not necessary. By 1936, 90% of peasants collectivized.

The Great Purges was a campaign of political repression in the Soviet Union which occurred from 1936 to 1938. It involved a large-scale purge of the Communist Party and government officials, repression of wealthy landlords and the Red Army leadership, widespread police surveillance, suspicion of saboteurs, counter-revolutionaries, imprisonment, and arbitrary executions. In Russian historiography, the period of the most intense purge, 1937–1938, is called Yezhovshchina (literally, "Yezhov phenomenon",[note 1] commonly translated as "times of Yezhov" or "doings of Yezhov"), after Nikolai Yezhov, the head of the Soviet secret police, the NKVD, who was executed a year after the purge. Modern historical studies estimate the total number of deaths due to Stalinist repression in 1937–38 to be between 681,692-1,200,000. These people were either killed or taken to Gulags. This was sparked by the Kinov Assassination, a party boss whom Stalin considered a threat to his rule. Much paranoia about criticism, “class enemies,” and fascist spies. Part of the purges were show trials, often with bloodstained confessions. As a result, 37,000 officers were purged, which may have weakened the Soviet position at the start of WWII.
Work camps. Numbers rise from thousands to hundreds of thousands. With purges, there was over a million. These purges were not focused on rehabilitation, but instead on productivist mentality.

Set up councils and ghettos between 1939-1942. Serve as intermediaries between Germans and Jews. Initially they tried to open relations with German.s These were based on two false assumptions: That middle level generals had power & Nazis would be economically partial. Goebbels jobs was to keep the home front happy, while the horrors happened on the front lines. To do this, there was a heavy use of propaganda, of which Goebbels was the head of. This propaganda used both fear and heroics as their message.

The evacuation of children in Germany during the World War II was designed to save children in Nazi Germany from the risks associated with the aerial bombing of cities, by moving them to areas thought to be less at risk. This was very unpopular.
Forced labor, pressures, collaborators over Europe. Drew from all over Europe.
1940-1941. 267 Days when London was bombed 71 times. 40,000 were killed. As a result, 800,000 children were sent to the countryside.

Kindertransport was a organised rescue effort that took place during the nine months prior to the outbreak of the Second World War. The United Kingdom took in nearly 10,000 predominantly Jewish children from Germany, Austria, Czechoslovakia, Poland, and the Free City of Danzig. The children were placed in British foster homes, hostels, schools and farms. Often they were the only members of their families who survived the Holocaust. Most importantly, the programme was supported, publicised and encouraged by the British Government, which waived some immigration requirements
Exiled French leader. Sent Jean Moulin back to France to coordinate 8 major resistance groups -> “National Council of the Resistance”. Eventually gained more support as tide turned.

1943 Conference where the planning of how to take back France. This also created the “Grand Alliance”. Part of this outcome was the decision to disallow for suing for separate peace. They all agree on D-Day.

The Grand Alliance, also known as The Big Three, was a military alliance consisting of the three major Allies of World War II: the Soviet Union, the United States, and the United Kingdom. It is often called the "Strange Alliance" because it united the world's greatest capitalist state, the greatest communist state and the greatest colonial power.
Aug 1942 - Feb 1943. Decisive soviet victory, but largest loss in a single fight in history. Germans wanted to attack the area so that they could get to the oil north of Stalingrad.

400,000 members, founded in 1942. They were more mainstream, conservative, nationalistic and didn’t welcome Jews. They were supported by the exiled Polish government in London. They were behind the Warsaw uprising.
Left wing group, smaller than the home army. They cooperated with the Red Army and aimed to create a pro-Soviet-Union government in Poland.

Katyln Massacre was a series of mass executions of Polish military officers and intelligentsia carried out by the Soviet Union, specifically the NKVD ("People's Commissariat for Internal Affairs", aka the Soviet secret police) in April and May 1940. Though the killings took place at several places, the massacre is named after the Katyn Forest, where some of the mass graves were first discovered. Every university graduate a military reserve officers, so decimated educated classes.

the Lublin Committee, was an executive governing authority established by the communists in Poland at the later stage of World War II. It was officially proclaimed on 22 July 1944 in Chełm, installed on 26 July in Lublin and placed formally under the direction of the State National Council (Krajowa Rada Narodowa, KRN). The PKWN was a provisional entity functioning in opposition to the Polish government-in-exile, the internationally recognized government of Poland. The PKWN exercised control over Polish territory retaken from Nazi Germany by the Soviet Red Army and the Polish People's Army. It was sponsored and controlled by the Soviet Union and dominated by Polish communists.
Partisan fighting against Soviets continuing even into 1950s, but unsuccessful. They were eventually hunted down by the Polish ministry.
Agreement among the “Great Powers” that Germany must surrender unconditionally, as well as Germany must go through demobilization and denazification.

Plan for Europes borders. This agreement split Germany into 4 zones, agreement that the soviets may only extract reparations from it’s zone of occupants. Sign that European countries were to be friendly towards the soviet union.

Between May and September 1945, 6-7 million displaced persons, mostly former forced laborers repatriated. Initially, western allies forced DPs from eastern Europe to return (Soviet Union, including Baltic states, Poland, Ukraine, Hungary, Romania). Then, backed off as tensions with Soviet Union heightened.

Eastern European countries forcing out Germans, May-August 1945. Unorganized, often by local authorities. German fear of local retribution. Between 15-30,000 Germans killed in Czechoslovakia immediately after the war.

Part of the Potsdam agreement.  12 million ethnic Germans expelled from 1944-1948. In accordance with the Potsdam agreement, there was the removal of Germans in Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary. This was organized and processed by the Allies. Later germans took over the process.

Founded in 1919 with the Treaty of Versailles. The organization had no power. The guiding philosophy was to create nation-states with homogeneous populations. This transformed how states view their “people”, from subjects to citizens.

On October 24th, 1945, United Nations came into existence in San Francisco. This organizations was founded to protect human rights, though it was up to sovereign nations to uphold. One problem was that only states can bring forth complaints/violations to the United Nations.

Founded in 1948, several key concepts. Natural: Inheres in the individual simply by virtue of being a person, Inalienable: Cannot be removed, Universal: Applies to everyone. To be protected by an international body that was founded a few years earlier, the United Nations.

UN War Crimes commission, collected evidence of war Grimes (1943-1948). No power to prosecute. These trials were called the Nuremberg Trials. The totality of war ushered in a transformative era internationally. Twenty four major Nazi leaders were tried (Hitler, Himmler, and Goebbels posthumously; Martin Bormann et al. in absentia). Partly denazification; partly response to horrors of total war. Albeit after the fact, holding “perpetrators” accountable for Holocaust, Trying to prevent future war/genocide, Unprecedented response to war.

UN General Assembly adopted on December 9, 1948. Effective starting January 12, 1951. Defined genocide in legal terms, Polish Jewish lawyer Raphael Lemkin advocated for it. All participating countries advised to prevent and punish actions of genocide in war and in peacetime.

First session held on January 17, 1946. Maintaining international peace and security. Accepting new members to the United Nations. Approving any changes to United Nations Charter. Powers include: Establishment of peacekeeping operations, international sanctions and authorization of Military action through Security Council resolutions. The only UN body with binding resolutions to members states. Veto power is given to five permanent members: China, France, Russia, United Kingdom, and United States.

“We shall not realize our objectives ... unless we are willing to help free peoples maintain their free institutions and their national integrity against aggressive movements that seek to impose upon them totalitarian regimes… I believe that it must be the policy of the US to support free peoples who are resisting attempted subjugation by armed minorities or by outside pressure.”
Or the Zhdanov Doctrine, 1947. 	Soviet response: outlining the anti-imperialist and democratic camp versus the imperialist and anti-democratic camp (themselves).

Economies on the brink of destruction in Europe. Fear of Europeans turning towards communism, American decide on the Marshall plan, which provides $13 billion to rebuild. Initially offered to all of Europe, but Soviets view as plot to expand western power. Only Western states accepted.
Creation of two blocs: Soviet and Western. NATO was the western bloc. This led to the creation of both West and East Germany.
Soviet answer to NATO.
Symbolic high-point when Soviets cut off supplies to Berlin. Former capital in Soviet zone of occupation. US responded by shipping everything in by planes.

First “hot” war of the Cold War. 	Korea had been under Japanese imperial control since 1910. Soviet Union not in Pacific theater until war in Europe over (1945). 	On August 8, Red Army into Manchuria and down to the 38th parallel in Korea: helped communists consolidate power. In September 1945, US accepted Japanese surrender south of the 38th parallel. US controlled southern half of the country. Soviet Union withdrew in 1948, US withdrew in 1949.
A proxy war. The Korean War is an instance of this, since the Soviets backed the communists, but the US backed the democratic side.

In Indochina, French tried to reassert power. Ho Chi Minh declared Vietnam’s independence from France in 1945. America initially supported them. Multi-faceted conflict. Soviets backed government in the North, Americans supported French in the South; Chinese supported Vietnamese rebels. Negotiations result in the Geneva Accords in 1954. Cease-fire and French agreed to withdraw. French-controlled Indochina split into Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam. Vietnam divided into North and South, with elections promised for 1956.
National coalitions against Europeans, led by Western-trained intellectuals (e.g. Ghandi).
Decolonization after World War II created many new nations. Stuck between throwing off colonial powers and facing Cold War pressures as newly independent countries.
Development of “second strike,” or ability to retaliate after an initial attack. Basically, if anyone fires a nuclear weapon, everyone will die.
OSS (Precursor to CIA) recruitment of over 1,500 German scientists to help develop weapons. Wernher von Braun as most famous.
Not everyone comforted by civil defense measures. Protest movements. Part of this is in 1957, “Göttingen 18” oppose move to arm West Germany with tactical nuclear weapons. Included Werner Heisenberg.

Early 1970s, new understanding that arms race was unsustainable. Easing of tensions between US and Soviet Union. With this came the Limited Test Ban Treaty, 1963. Significantly restricted nuclear testing: all atmospheric, underwater, and outer space tested to be halted. Underground still allowed

SALT I Treaty signed 1972. Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty: Interim Agreement on the Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms. Limited countries to two ABM sites, froze number of ICBMs. In 1979, SALT II was agreed to, but US Congress never passed it. 	Limited nuclear arsenals and technology.

Tension between rebuilding/moving on and confronting the past. In both eastern and western sectors, Reeducation, Removing propaganda from schools, Führer cult had to be discredited. Part of this was renaming streets, parks, as well as removing people with Nazi ties from positions of power. In Germany, the initial view was that the Nazis had lied to and betrayed the German people (“Had gone too far”).

New generation that grew up in relative affluence came of age, started asking questions and challenged older generation on a number of fronts: lack of real political alternatives, traditional gender norms, old-fashioned views on education. They also protested the Vietnam war, US involvement in South East Asia, as well as Silence of older generation about collaboration with Nazis.
Influenced by Marxist and Anti-colonial writers, like Frantz Fanon, Ho Chi Minh, Che Guevara, Mao Zedong. Were domestic terrorists. Eventually arrested and imprisoned.
Promised in the 1990 Two-Plus- Four Treaty that “peace will emanate from German soil”. Creation of independent German nation.
